The only reason why sub-section (2) has been inserted is to add to the definition of sub- section (I) something which would apply only in the Union Territory of Del11i. The reason is obvious. The Central Government and the Delhi Development Authority in Delhi own and p,)sscss so many public premises as are not possessed by the Government or ihc Gov- ernment Corporations or statutory authorities in any other place 0f comparable area. It is because of the tremendous concentration of C public premises in Delhi that the Municipal Corporation and the Delhi Development Authority were included in the definitioa of owners of public premises. This being a special reason it i-s quite understand- able why sub-section (2) has been added in respect of the Union Territory of Delhi alone. What was objected to in that case was that two alternative procedures B should net be made available to the owners of public premises with- out adequate guidelines to show which of the alternative remedte:5 should be adopted in which circumstances. It was held in that case that such guidelines were clearly spelt out fr'.)m the preamble and C the provisions of the Public Premises (Eviction of Unauthorised OC{:upants) Act and, therefore, irrespective of the fact that section 15 of the said Act excludes resort to civil -::ourts for the purpose of ob- taining eviction of unauthorised occupants, the said Act was not un- D E G H constitutional as being contrary to Article 14 of the Constitution. 7. The situation before us appears to be as follows : On the one hand, the relationship of landlord and tenant in respect of pre- mises except Government premises can be the ~ub_jcct matter of litiga- tion under the Delhi Rent Control Act. On the other hand, the evic- tion of unauthorised occupants from rublic premises can be the subject of appropriate proceedings under the Public Premises (Eviction of Unauthorised Occupants) Act, l 971. To us, the question is 110t as to which Act prevails over the other or takes away the jurisdiction from tht· other. On the other hand, we would follow the principles of harmonisation Iaid down by the Supreme Court in Shri Ram Narain v. The Simla Ban~dng and Industrial Co. Ltd. ( 1956) SCR 603 (2). In that case also, where the two statutes concerned were equally appli- cable to th·~ facts of the case, the Supreme Ccurt cleared its way by stating at page 615 of the report as follows : ''It is, therefore, desirable to determ'ine the overriding effect of one or the other of the relevant provisions in these two Acts, in a given case, on much broader considerations of the purpose and policy underlying the two Acts and the clear intendment conveyed by the language of the relevant. provisions therein." 8. By the words "overriding effect" is not to be understood an implied repeal. All that we are concerned with is this : Each of these 1 two statutes is available fm the initiating such proceedings as is most appropriate to the particular cause of action. For, for instance, the tenant ljas his own cause of action and he makes an application under a provision of the Delhi Rent Control Act, such as fixation of standard rent, then the Controller will have jurisdiction under the said Act, if section 3 does not exclude the premises from the purview of the Act. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- TruePrint™ source: ILR (Delhi), © 2024 Delhi High Court. The Nason is simple. The Controller is exercising jurisdiction under the DeU'li Rent Control Act. It can n-ever be argued that the jurisdiction given by that statute is taken away by some other statute which does not have the C same ol~jcct in view and which cannot furnish 3 defence in a pro- ceeding which is under a different statute. Similarly, if the cause of action for eviction of a tenant arises in favour of the landlord who is the owner of a public premises within the meaning of section 2 ( e) of the Public Premises (Eviction of Unauthorised Occupant~) Act. then D the approfriate proceedings can be initiated by such a landlord before in E~tate Officer or rather an Estate Officer can take proceedings in respect of sueh public premises. By the same parity of reasoning, as given above. the tenant cannot plead before the Estale Officer that the jurisdiction of the Estate Officer in respect of hi~ tenancy, E is taken away by the reason that the Controller would F also have the jurisdiction, if the landlord had chos~n to institute the eviction proceedings against the tenant before tbe Controller. After all, it is the choice of the dominis litis to seek the prnpcr forum to vindicate l1is cause o~ action. We have not been shown nny prjnciple or authority to support the argument that jurisdiction which admittedly exists under a particular enactment is to be deemed to be taken away or cut down merely because some other enactment also would have applied if the dominis litis has chosen to institute a proceeding in the other forum. G We are of the view therefore, that no question of conflict between such two enactments can arise, inasmuch as a particular proceeding can be instituted under one of the two acts and the juri8dic:tkn ha~: to b~ considered on the al!egations made by the perscn who institutes the procteding under any of the two Acts. 111e ckfenc~ cannot allege lack H of jurisdiction on the ground that the other Act is also av2ilable for the initiation of such proceeding. Such a question cannot arise unless and until the person initiating the proceedings choose" to go to the I other forum. 9. It may be also mentioned here that the question of conflict between an order issued under a Central Act and another Central statute had also been brought up before the Supreme Court in Hari- shankar Bagla v. The State of Madhya Pradesh, (1955) 1 SCR 380(3). Such a by-passing, according to the Court's observation at page 392, did not amount to repeal or abrogation of the other Act. We are of the view that it is this kind of harmoniousion which is to be attempted between the two Acts before us. B 10. A'> pointed out above, the objects an<.l policies of the two statutes are quite different from each other. The Delhi Rent Control Act respects the distinction between public premises and other premises which is the basis of the Public Premises (Eviction of Unauthorised ,C Occupants) Act, 1971. Section 3 excludes Government premises from the purview of the Delhi Rent Control Act. All that has happened ls that the definition of public premises under the Public Premises (Evic- tion of Unauthorised Occupants) Act is wider than the definition of Government premises under the Delhi Rent Control Act, 1978. But D the policy of the legislature is consistent. It is to exclude public premises from the testriction imposed on eviction and on enhancement of rent by tlie rent control legislation and to take away public premises from such rcsltictions and to enable the owners of public premises not only E to e,'ict the unauthorised occupants expeditiously and to limit the right of appeal, but also to enable the owners of public premises to charge damages fro_m persons in unauthorised occupation. Thfa clearly distin- guishes the Public Premises (Eviction of Unauthorised Oc,!upants) Act from the Delhi Rent Control Act. This is an additional reason for the conclusion that if a proceeding is pending under the Public Premises F (Eviction of Unauthorised Occupants) Act extraneous considerations based upon the Delhi Rent Control Act cannot be introduced in arguing t1rnt the jurisdiction given by the former Act is somehow taken away by the latter. G 11. For these reasons the three contention<; urged before us fail. As for t:he merits of the question are concerned as to whether a cause of action has arisen for Respondent No. 1 to terminate the lease of the petitioner and thereby render the petitioner as unauthorised occupant H within the definition of "unauthorised occupant" in section 2(g) of the Public Premises (Eviction of Unauthorised Occupants) Act, 1971 the proper forum is the Estate Officer and the appellate authority is the District Judge. It would not be right for us to consider that question 1 because that would be depriving the petitioner opportunity of adducing the necessary evidence and also the benefit of an appeal under the Act. After a1J, Article 226 of the Constitution is available to the petitioner after final orders under the Act are passed. We are, therefore, not making any observation as to the merits of the case. Mr. Gokhale for the petitioner, orally prayed for grant of a certificate of fitness for appeal to the Supreme Court under Article 13 3 of the Constitution. Since the conclusion arrived at above is based on the harmonious interpretation of the two statutes, following principles laid down by the Supreme Court, and since no decision has been cited B for the petitioner in support of the argument that the jurisdiction under one Act can be taken away by showing that such a proceeding can also be entertained un.der some other Act, we do not think that a substantial question of .law of general importance which needs to be decided by C the S_upreme .Court has arisen in ·this case. As for the argument regard- ing legislative competence of the Parliameat to legislate as to the prr)- perty of statutory Corporation, it is not necessary for us to rely upon Entry 32 of List I, in respect of the Union Territory of Delhi. The argument aboq.t the legislative competence of the Parliament may be D open to a petitioner who can show that legislative competence is restricted to State legislature alone. Since there is no difference between the State legislature and Parliament in respect of Union Territories that contention cannot furnish a good ground for the grant of a certificate. The oral a,pplication for certificate is dismissed. E S.N.C. Petition dismissed.
